content:
Content: Palace of Westminster (Houses of Parliament) is a building that serves as the home of the British Parliament in London, England. The building is a complex of Gothic Revival-style structures, including the famous clock tower known as Big Ben (now officially called the Elizabeth Tower).

Context: The Palace of Westminster was built in the mid-19th century, with the majority of the current structure dating from the late 1800s. The building was designed by architect Charles Barry and was intended to replace the old Palace of Westminster, which was destroyed by fire in 1834.

Function: The Palace of Westminster serves as the seat of the British government and the home of the two houses of Parliament: the House of Commons and the House of Lords. It is a symbol of British democracy and the center of the country's political life. The building is also a tourist attraction and a popular landmark in London, attracting millions of visitors each year. The Palace of Westminster is also an important architectural and cultural monument, reflecting the history, values, and traditions of the British people.
